qas.question: How many contradictory facts does the problem of the direction of time arise from?
What kind of physical laws are time-reversal invariant?
If if a cinematographic film were taken by means of physical  laws and then played backwards, it would still portray what?
How is our experience of time at the macro level?
What do we not have memories of?
What do we experience as time-reversal invariant?
What can we influence besides the future?

context: The problem of the direction of time arises directly from <a0_0>two<a0_0/> contradictory facts. Firstly, <b5_0>the <a1_0>fundamental<a1_0/> physical laws<b5_0/> are time-reversal invariant; if a cinematographic film were taken of any process describable by means of the aforementioned laws and then played backwards, it would still portray a <a2_0>physically possible process<a2_0/>. Secondly, our experience of <b6_0>time, at the macroscopic<b6_0/> level, is <a3_0>not time-reversal invariant<a3_0/>. Glasses can fall and break, but shards of glass cannot reassemble and fly up onto tables. We have memories of the past, and none of <a4_0>the future<a4_0/>. We feel we can't change <b7_0>the past<b7_0/> but can influence the future.
